awd_titl_txt: Elucidating the Fundamental Properties of the Nucleon with Dispersive Techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern nuclear physics and particle physics are concerned with understanding the fundamental parameters and symmetries of nature. A crucial new piece of this puzzle has recently become available with the Nobel-prize-winning discovery of the neutrino flavor oscillations, which showed that neutrinos had masses contrary to the paradigm of the Standard Model. Today, the field of neutrino physics enters the precision era, with accelerator-based neutrino oscillation experiments taking center stage in the experimental program in the US and in the world. To understand neutrino interactions with nuclei in the detector requires accurate modeling of strong interactions—the force that binds the nucleus together. The PI will do this using state-of-the-art analytical techniques, focusing on the quantities of most direct relevance to neutrino experiments at Fermilab and elsewhere. This project will thus provide the necessary theoretical foundations needed to support these experimental breakthroughs. It will also provide excellent training ground for students and young researchers. 

The focus of this project is be on a specific piece of physics that plays a crucial role in modeling neutrino interactions at GeV energies: the nucleon axial form factor. It describes the structure of the nucleon which is not a point-like particle but has a structure that is still not well known. The PI and her collaborators will develop a physics-based framework to accurately model this form factor, based on the methods of chiral perturbation theory and dispersive techniques. Moreover, a bridge to numerical evaluations on the lattice will be established by applications of various analytical constraints, such as current conservation. Agreement with various electron scattering data will also be explored. This will support state-of-the-art nuclear physics experiments at Thomas Jefferson Laboratory, particularly GlueX or CLAS, as well as the upcoming precision neutrino-nucleus scattering experiments at Fermilab and worldwide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Today, the field of neutrino physics enters the precision era, with accelerator-based neutrino oscillation experiments taking center stage in the experimental program in the US and in the world. To understand neutrino interactions with nuclei in the detector requires accurate modelling of strong interactions--the force that binds the nucleus together.

The aim of this project was to provide the necessary theoretical foundations needed to support the neutrino experiments at Fermilab and elsewhere.

Our focus was on a specific piece of physics that plays a crucial role in modelling neutrino interactions at GeV energies: the nucleon axial form factor. It describes the structure of the nucleon which is not a point-like particle but has a structure that is still not well known.

In recent years, lattice QCD, which simulates strong interactions numerically using large supercomputing resources, has seen considerable advances in its application to the fundamental properties of baryons. Modeling of the baryonic form factors and in particular the nucleon axial form factor on the lattice is significantly more challenging than modeling of meson form factors. The baryonic case requires considerably more statistical power, to combat lower signal-to-noise. The problem of excited state contamination is also severe and must be carefully addressed. There is natural synergy between the lattice advancements and those in neutrino physics. On the neutrino physics side, it promises to improve our understanding of cross sections, which would be very beneficial. On the lattice side, neutrino data provide a validation framework for numerical predictions.

While such a general connection is clear, what was needed is a more concrete study: a framework to gauge the impact of lattice results on specific neutrino measurements. This would allow one to establish how the neutrino data are sensitive to certain features of the form-factor, such as different functional dependence.

We successfully developed a quantitative bridge between the lattice QCD results and neutrino scattering data. We compared predictions of the different lattice groups to the data and identified improvements that should be included in the event generators. This study informs the lattice QCD community where should their efforts be focused to make the most impact for the neutrino experiments NOvA and DUNE (Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment). This is important since lattice calculations are extremely computationally demanding. At the same time, this connection has opened new avenues to future improvements in the axial form factor determination combining lattice QCD results with analytical methods.

In the course of the project we trained 2 undergraduate and 3 graduate students, as well as 2 postdoctoral fellows.
